I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Management  System  and 
Legislative Mechanism of Nonprofit Organizations was included in the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) TA pipeline for the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in the December 2010 country 
programming mission, responding to the government’s request. Dialogue with the National 
Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) and the Ministry of Finance clarified the policy 
and  institutional  context,  and  priorities for  ADB  support.  Agreement  was  reached  with  the 
government on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost and financing 
arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.1 
 
II.      ISSUES 
2.  The nonprofit sector in the PRC started developing at the beginning of the successful 
economic and social reform launched in 1978. As the political, economic and social environment 
evolved, awareness about the importance of social development increased, and the government 
explored new approaches for the provision of social services and to address poverty issues. As 
a result, the number of civil society organizations in the PRC increased dramatically, from 4,446 
registered organizations in 1988 to 414,614 in 2009.2 The government defines three types of 
nonprofit  organizations  (NPOs)  under  its  current  registration  system:  social  organizations, 
private  non-enterprise  units  (PNUs),  and  foundations,  which  are  commonly  referred  as 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs). 
  
3.  Social  organizations  are  officially  defined  as  NPOs  that  are  formed  voluntarily  by 
Chinese  citizens  in  order  to  realize  the  shared  objectives  of  their  members,  carrying  out 
activities in accordance with their charter.3 They may take the form of a charity organization, a 
federation, an industrial association, a research institute, or an academic society. PNUs are 
officially defined as nonprofit social service organizations that are using non-state-owned assets, 
which are formed by nonprofit government institutions, social organizations, social entities and 
individual citizens.4 They may include nonprofit and privately run schools, hospitals, museums 
or scientific research institutes. Foundations are private organizations set up with funds donated 
by either domestic or overseas organizations or individuals5 to promote scientific research, 
cultural education, social welfare, environment protection, or poverty reduction.  
 
4.  In addition to the growth in the number of NPOs, the capacity and scope of the activities 
and roles undertaken by NPOs and public institutions have expanded. In particular, during the 
2008 Wenchuan earthquake, the engagement and support from NPOs resulted in a better 
perception by the public of their functions. Under the Twelfth Five-Year Plan (2011–2015), 
NPOs are expected to play an increasing role in the provision of basic services. To that effect, a 
large number of public institutions may become legally registered as NPOs, which will require 
improving their administration and public reporting system. In this process, it is necessary to 
address the existing constraints hampering the development and impact of NPOs through the 
enhancement of their management systems and legislative safeguards.

5.  While three sets of regulations6 establish the current legal framework for NPOs in the 
PRC, there is room to further enhance the capacity of NPOs to provide social services and 
foster inclusive growth by: (i) strengthening standards, safeguard requirements, and the scope 
of responsibility; (ii) establishing mechanisms to enforce the rights and obligations of NPOs, in 
particular  registration  and  compliance  with  the  law;  and  (iii)  reinforcing  accountability, 
management and monitoring systems.  
 
6.  More specifically, due to the weakness of the legal framework governing their operations, 
NPOs are required to seek a government department as a sponsor and supervisor prior to their 
registration with the Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) or other designated central  and local 
registration authorities, depending on the nature of the NPO. As it is often difficult to locate a 
sponsor, NPOs frequently operate without legal registration, and the number of operating NPOs 
is thus estimated to be significantly larger than that of registered NPOs. As non-registered 
NPOs operate without a legal status, they are largely unaware of their rights and obligations, 
including those related to taxation. In addition, there are restrictions on the number of NPOs that 
can  intervene  in  a  specific  geographical  area  and  scope  (e.g.,  if  an  NPO  addressing 
environment protection is registered at the city level, no new organization for environmental 
protection will be authorized to register in the city). 
 
7.  With regard to the branches of international NGOs or overseas foundations, while they 
may register and be subject to national regulations, it would be necessary to develop specific 
arrangements to integrate their respective overseas and domestic regulations.  
 
8.  Establishment of a monitoring and supervision structure for NPOs should be a priority in 
the context of increasing the positive contribution made by NPOs to the provision of services. In 
addition, the Twelfth Five-Year Plan (2011–2015) advocates that a greater role be played by 
NPOs in providing social services that foster inclusive growth and employment generation, and 
thereby contribute to poverty reduction. However, given the existing constraints, it is essential to 
enhance the capacity of NPO administrators and government officials to mobilize resources, 
administer projects and funds, conduct safeguard assessments, and monitor and evaluate the 
effect of NPO participation on poverty reduction.  
 
9.  The TA  directly  supports  the  ADB  country  partnership  strategy  (CPS) for the  PRC 
(2008–2010) and the anticipated priorities of the CPS now under preparation.7 The TA builds on 
the findings of Nongovernment Organization-Government Partnerships in Village-Level Poverty 
Alleviation,8 in particular the successfully tested model for government services procurement 
from NGOs. The TA will also consider experiences and lessons regarding community-driven 
development  practices  reviewed  under  the  ongoing  East–West  Partnerships  for  Poverty 
Reduction.9

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be improved contribution of NPOs to poverty reduction and inclusive 
growth in the PRC. The outcome will be strengthened policy and regulatory framework for NPOs 
in the PRC. 
 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have three main outputs and diverse deliverables as specified below. First, 
the TA will produce a research report and a series of policy recommendations focusing on four 
areas: (i) identifying challenges and options to support the development of NPOs in the PRC; (ii) 
improving the regulatory framework and legislative safeguards for NPOs, based on theoretical 
and practical analysis of international and domestic experience; (iii) revising the taxation system, 
internal management mechanism and operational guidelines for NPOs; and (iv) establishing a 
monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system to measure the contribution of NPOs to inclusive 
growth and social development. Policy recommendations will be drawn from: (i) an analysis of 
the  current  domestic  experiences,  challenges  and  different  options  for  NPO  structures, 
operations, and accountability in the PRC, including in-depth assessment of selected pilot cases; 
and (ii) a review of relevant international NGO governance experience with lessons for the PRC. 
 
12.  Second, the TA will provide options for regulations and related systems of registration, 
reporting and oversight based on the first output and findings from the pilot cases. Key activities 
include:  (i)  an  overseas  study  visit  to  learn  from  successful  NPO  management  and  legal 
systems; (ii) design, implementation and evaluation of a pilot program; and (iii) training sessions 
for NPO administrators and government officials.  
 
13.  Third,  the  TA  will  disseminate  research  findings  and  policy  suggestions  through 
seminars and the publication of a bilingual policy note.  Two national workshops (inception and 
midterm) and one international seminar will be organized to discuss NPO policy; a bilingual 
policy note will be compiled and disseminated among the NDRC, relevant government agencies 
and selected NPOs; and a final conference on findings and recommendations will be convened.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000 equivalent. The government has requested ADB 
to finance $400,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will finance the balance of the 
cost,  equivalent  to  $200,000,  through  provision  of  office  space  and  equipment,  office 
communications,  remuneration  and  per  diem  for  counterpart  staff,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. (See Appendix 2 for details of the cost estimates and financing plan.) 
 
15.  The cost estimate is based on engaging expert inputs equivalent to a total of 24 person-
months of individual consulting services,10 including two international consultants for 5 person-
months and four national consultants for a total of 19 person-months. The consultant team will 
be responsible for producing the TA outputs and deliverables in a timely and effective manner, 
and for organizing and carrying out all TA activities. The consultants’ terms of reference are in 
Appendix 3. TA support for workshops may include costs related to the venue, equipment rental,

logistics and administrative support, and other expenditures with prior agreement from ADB. In 
line with standard ADB procedures, the TA will not support implementing agency management

D.   Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 26 months, from October 2011 to November 2013. The 
Department of Economic System Reform (DESR) of NDRC will be both the executing and 
implementing agency for the TA. The DESR will be responsible for establishing and chairing a 
TA steering committee. The committee will be composed of representatives from MOCA, the 
Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Education, the State Council Leading Group for Poverty 
Alleviation and Development, the National Population and Family Planning Commission, the 
selected  pilot  program  localities,  and  other  government  agencies  concerned,  as  well  as 
representatives of relevant NPOs, including the All-China Women’s Federation. The steering 
committee will convene as needed, and be regularly consulted and invited to participate in TA 
activities. 
 
17.  The  DESR  will  provide  a  suitably  furnished  office  with  computers,  utilities,  and 
telecommunications access (including broadband internet connection), materials, maps, data 
and documents as required under the TA, and will cover the cost of office utilities for the 
consultants. The DESR will also cover remuneration and per diem for counterpart staff. The 
DESR will designate a TA focal point with strong English speaking and writing skills, and 
facilitate all TA activities and links to local government and providers to ensure the effective 
implementation of the TA. 
 
18.   In consultation with the DESR, ADB will recruit national and international experts to 
provide inputs as formal consultants, short-term resource persons, and task-specific experts. 
The international and national consultants will be selected and engaged on an individual basis 
by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time). Individual consultants will be chosen based on their academic qualifications 
and relevant work experience. To facilitate implementation, ADB may establish an advance 
facility for the DESR, and/or utilize direct payment (e.g., for workshop venues). The proceeds of 
the TA will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). All procurement under the TA will be carried out in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Management System and Legislative 
Mechanism for Nonprofit Organizations and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
   
1.  A total of 24 person-months of consulting services (two international consultants for 5 
person-months and four national consultants for a total of 19 person-months) will be required. 
The consultants will be responsible for effectively producing the outputs and deliverables of the 
technical  assistance  (TA)  in  a  timely  manner,  and  for  organizing  and  carrying  out  all  TA 
activities,  working  as  a  team  and  coordinating  with  each  other  as  necessary  under  the 
supervision of the team leader. 
 
2.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  recruit  consultants  in  accordance  with  its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Experts will serve 
to introduce international best practice; provide in-depth local knowledge; and advise on policy 
options, challenges, and the implications of various courses of actions. The experts may be 
independent consultants, or recruited from consulting firms, research institutes, think tanks, 
academic institutions, government research arms, or nongovernment organizations.  
 
3.  The areas of expertise of the engaged consultants must be consistent with the scope of 
the TA. The international legal specialist on nongovernment organization (NGO) management 
systems and legislation (3 person-months) will possess strong expertise in recommending legal 
frameworks and management procedures related to NGOs in several developing and developed 
countries.  The  international  specialist  on  the  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  of  NGO 
interventions  (2  person-months)  will  have  expertise  in  developing  reporting  and  impact 
evaluation systems to measure nonprofit organization (NPO) contributions to poverty reduction 
and social development in several countries. The national expert on NPO laws (13 person-
months) will act as the team leader. The expert will be familiar with the laws of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) regulating NPOs and will have the expertise needed to design and 
assess  regulatory  frameworks,  internal  governance  systems,  safeguard  and  accountability 
schemes,  as  well  as  the  necessary  enforcement  mechanisms.  The  national  social  policy 
specialist  (3  person-months)  will  have  expertise  in  engaging  civil  society  organizations  in 
poverty reduction and social development programs. The national fiscal expert on NPO taxation 
(2 person-months) will be familiar with the taxation system and fiscal rules applying to NPOs. 
The national expert on public services procurement (1 person-month) will have experience in 
developing mechanisms for government procurement of NGO services.  
 
A.   Team  Leader  and  Expert  on  Nonprofit  Organization  Laws  (national,  13  person-
months, intermittent) 
 
4.   The  national  legal  expert  on  NPO  policy,  regulations,  internal  management  and 
accountability  systems,  acting  as  the  team  leader,  will  have  a  university  degree  in  law, 
preferably  at  the  postgraduate  level  or  its  equivalent,  and  at  least  12  years  of  relevant 
experience with developing regulatory frameworks and mechanisms for NPO operations in the 
PRC. The consultant will also have expertise in designing and assessing laws and regulations 
related to NPO operations, and the necessary enforcement mechanisms. The expert will: 
 
(i)  serve  as  the  team  leader  of  the  national  and  international  consultants,  and 
ensure timely completion of all outputs of the TA, and good team coordination; 
(ii)  critically review current regulations and management systems of NPOs in the 
PRC, including consultations with NPOs (legally and not legally registered) and 
their constituents to seek feedback and learn from their experience; 
(iii)  carry out field investigations for the design, implementation and evaluation of  
selected pilot programs in the PRC;

B.   Legal  Expert  on  Nongovernment  Organization  Management  and  Legislation 
(international, 3 person-months, intermittent)  
 
5.   The international legal specialist on NGO management system and legislation will have a 
university degree in law, preferably at the postgraduate level or its equivalent, and at least 12 
years of relevant experience in legal frameworks and management procedures related to NGOs 
in several developing and developed countries. Subject to the supervision of the team leader, 
and working in close coordination with the team, the expert will: 
 
(i)   review the existing international experience on NGO management systems and 
legal frameworks; 
(ii)    consult with NPOs (legally and not legally registered) and their constituents about 
their views and suggestions on NGO management systems and legislation; 
(iii)      draft  recommendations  in  English  regarding  the  management  system  and 
legislation for NPOs in the PRC;  
(iv)      seek feedback from national experts, government agencies, and NPOs (legally 
and not legally registered) and their constituents on the recommendations;  
(v)       provide inputs in English to that part of the TA final report and policy note related 
to the international NGO experience; and  
(vi)      contribute to workshops and the final conference as requested. 
 
C.   Specialist on Monitoring and Evaluation of Nongovernment Organization Actions 
(international, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
6.   The international specialist on M&E of NGO interventions will have a university degree in 
law, social sciences, development economics or related fields, preferably at the postgraduate 
level or its equivalent, and at least 12 years of relevant experience in developing reporting and 
impact evaluation systems to measure the contributions of NPOs to poverty reduction and social 
development in several countries. Subject to the supervision of the team leader, and working in 
close coordination with the team, the expert will: 
 
(i)  review international experience and methodology for M&E of NGO provision of 
social services;  
(ii)   undertake selected field visits to collect experiences on M&E of NPO operations in 
the  PRC,  including  seeking  feedback  from  NPOs  (legally  and  not  legally 
registered) and their constituents;

E.   Expert on Nonprofit Organization Taxation (national, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
8.   The national expert on taxation and public service procurement will have a university 
degree in public finance, economics or related fields, preferably at the postgraduate level or its 
equivalent, and at least 10 years of relevant experience on the taxation system and rules 
applying  to  NPOs.  Subject  to  the  supervision  of  the  team  leader,  and  working  in  close 
coordination with the team, the expert will: 
 
(i)  review national and international practices on taxation of NGO operations;  
(ii)  undertake  selected  field  visits  to  collect  experiences  on  taxation  of  NPO 
operations; 
(iii)  interview national and international experts, and NPOs (legally and not legally 
registered) and their constituents, to get their feedback on research findings and 
suggestions to improve the taxation system for NPO services in the PRC; 
(iv)  prepare a report in English, including policy recommendations, related to the 
taxation mechanisms for NPO services in the PRC; 
(v)  provide inputs in English to that part of the TA final report and policy note related 
to taxation; and  
(vi)  act as a resource person during the workshops and final conference.

Appendix 3  11 
 
 
F.   Expert on Public Procurement (national, 1 person-month) 
 
9.   The expert on public service procurement will have a university degree in law, public 
administration,  public  finance  or  related  fields,  preferably  at  the  postgraduate  level  or  its 
equivalent, and at least 10 years of relevant experience developing mechanisms for government 
procurement of NPO services in the PRC. Subject to the supervision of the team leader, and 
working in close coordination with the team, the expert will: 
 
(i)  review national and international practices on government procurement of NGO 
services;  
(ii)  undertake selected field visits to collect experiences on procurement of NPO 
operations; 
(iii)  interview national and international experts, and NPOs (legally and not legally 
registered) and their constituents, to get their feedback on research findings and 
suggestions to improve the procurement mechanisms for NPO services in the 
PRC; 
(iv)  prepare a report in English, including policy recommendations, related to the 
procurement system for NPO services in the PRC; 
(v)  provide inputs in English to that part of the TA final report and policy note related 
to procurement; and  
(vi)  act as a resource person during the workshops and final conference.
